abstracts.cdata!:
Overall, the project was satisfactory,
            and sustainability is likely. The main objective of
            establishing a community-based forest management, was
            accomplished through the empowerment of user groups, by
            active training and extension programs, in particular,
            through the transfer of forest resources management, to
            these groups. The key lessons demonstrate that setting the
            appropriate policies and legislation, was paramount, thus
            the Bank has a constructive role to play in support of
            policy changes, in the early stages of the project cycle.
            However, whether government institutions' capacity, can
            support large-scale programs in the long run, remains
            questionable, as demand for further support increases,
            competition may arise in the formation of new groups. This
            could be strengthened through private sector involvement.
            Emphasis on forest ecosystems restoration suggest a valued
            environmental service to local users, for it reduces soil
            erosion, and improves water availability. The project also
            demonstrated that forest user groups, appropriately managed
            their financial accounts, with community supervision,
            strengthening ownership. It is further suggested, that
            project design should incorporate mechanisms to ensure
            coordination with parallel programs, as well as flexibility
            to adjust project activities, as needed.

18152135.theme: Environmental policies and institutions,Biodiversity,Rural services and infrastructure,Gender,Participation and civic engagement
18152135.majtheme: Environment and natural resource management,Rural development,Social dev/gender/inclusion

abstracts.cdata!:
The project will assist the Government
            to implement important components of its forestry master
            plan and forestry sector policy by helping to establish a
            system to conserve and expand the forest resources which
            sustain traditional farming systems in the hills. The
            project will be implemented by the Ministry of Forests and
            Soil Conservation (MFSC), Department of Forests (FD),
            Department of Forests and Plant Research (DFPR), and User
            Groups over a period of seven years. The project consists of
            four components: (i) an institutional support component to
            strengthen FD's organization to enable it to identify
            and establish about 4,000 User Groups and transfer
            management responsibility for some 400,000 ha of forest land
            to them; (ii) a plantation establishment and management
            component, under which at least 56,300 ha of forest will be
            established, and about 18 million seedlings distributed to
            farmers for private planting; (iii) a training and extension
            component to communicate the Government's Community
            Forestry policy to FD staff and the communities; and (iv) a
            research component which will help DFPR to generate improved
            silvicultural techniques to conserve and increase the
            productivity of forest resources.
